maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about permissions that an NFS server grants to exported NFS shares.
The Get-NfsSharePermission cmdlet gets information about access permissions granted by a Network File System (NFS) server that has an NFS share configured.
Specifies the name of an NFS share.
Specifies a client name. The client name can be a host name or IP address, netgroup name, or client group name. To specify the type of client, use the ClientType parameter.
Specifies a client type. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- host
- clientgroup
- netgroup
Specifies the type of access to get for an NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- no-access
- readonly
- readwrite
A client can have either read-only or read/write access. Only the All Machines group can have all three types of access.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the scoped network name of an NFS share.
On a local share, NetworkName is the host name. On a cluster, it is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the path of an NFS share.
Specifies a client name. The client name can be a host name or IP address, netgroup name, or client group name. To specify the type of client, use the ClientType parameter.
Specifies a client type. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- host
- clientgroup
- netgroup
Specifies the type of access to get for an NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- no-access
- readonly
- readwrite
A client can have either read-only or read/write access. Only the All Machines group can have all three types of access.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

The default is the current session on the local computer.

- host
- clientgroup
- netgroup

Specifies the scoped network name of an NFS share.
On a local share, NetworkName is the host name. On a cluster, it is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

- readonly

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 1: Get all permissions for a specified NFS share ---
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-NfsSharePermission -Name "Export" ClientName : All Machines ClientType : Built-in Group Name : Export Path : C:\shares\Export Permission : READ, WRITE AllowRootAccess : ALLOW ACCESS LanguageEncoding : ansi

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the permissions for an NFS share named Export.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get read/write permissions for a specified NFS share

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the read/write permissions for an NFS share named Export.

maml:description.maml:para: Grants permission to access shares that an NFS server exports.

The Grant-NfsSharePermission cmdlet configures access permissions to a Network File System (NFS) share that an NFS server exports. You can use Grant-NfsSharePermission to grant permissions for a share by using a specified name or path.
You can choose the type of permissions to provide to client computers, netgroups, or client groups.
You can choose to fence the language encoding across individual hosts or netgroups. Services for NFS supports fencing of shares by using the following principals:
- Hosts
- Client groups
- Netgroups
Specifies the name of an NFS share.
Specifies a client name. The client name can be a host name or IP address, netgroup name, or client group name. To specify the type of client, use the ClientType parameter.
Specifies a client type. Use the builtin client type only when the ClientName parameter value is All Machines.
Valid values are:
- host
- clientgroup
- netgroup
- builtin
Specifies the type of access to grant for an NFS share. Valid values are:
- no-access
- readonly
- readwrite
Specifies the type of language encoding used for access permissions configured on an NFS share. You can use only one of the following values for a share:
- euc-jp (Japanese)
- euc-tw (Chinese)
- euc-kr (Korean)
- shift-jis (Japanese)
- big5 (Chinese)
- ksc5601 (Korean)
- gb2312-80 (Simplified Chinese)
- ansi
Specifies whether to grant the UNIX root user access to an NFS share.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the scoped network name of an NFS share.
On a local share, NetworkName is the host name. On a cluster, it is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

- builtin

- shift-jis (Japanese)

- ksc5601 (Korean)
- gb2312-80 (Simplified Chinese)
- ansi
Specifies whether to grant the UNIX root user access to an NFS share.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Grant NFS share permissions to a specified client computer

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command grants read/write access to a share named Export for a computer named contoso-fs.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Grant NFS share permissions to a specified client group

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command grants read-only access to a share named Export for a client group named contoso-clientgroup.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Grant NFS share permissions to a specific UNIX computer with root user access

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command grants read access to a share named Export for a computer specifying its IP address, and also grants UNIX root user access.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a client group on an NFS server.

The New-NfsClientGroup cmdlet creates a Network File System (NFS) client group on a target computer. You can add one or more client computers to the new client group by using the AddMember parameter. You can also add and remove members of the client group by using the Set-NfsClientgroup cmdlet.
Specifies a name for a new client group.
Specifies an array of host names or IP addresses of client computers to add to the new client group.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of host names or IP addresses of client computers to add to the new client group.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a client group and add members by using host names
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-NfsClientGroup -ClientGroupName "Contoso-Group1" -AddMember ("joe-desktop", "bill-laptop") ClientGroupMembers : {joe-desktop,bill-laptop} ClientGroupName : Contoso-Group1 PSComputerName :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a client group named Contoso-Group1 and adds client computers to the new client group by using the host names of the client computers.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 2: Create a client group that has no members -----
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-NfsClientGroup -Name "Contoso-Group2" ClientGroupMembers : ClientGroupName : Contoso-Group2 PSComputerName :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a client group named Contoso-Group2. No members are added to the new client group.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create a client group and add a member by using an IP address
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-NfsClientGroup -Name "Contoso-Group2" -AddMember "10.121.24.132" ClientGroupMembers : {10.121.24.132} ClientGroupName : Contoso-Group2 PSComputerName :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a client group named Contoso-Group2 and adds a client computer that has the IP address 10.121.24.132 to the client group.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an NFS file share.

The New-NfsShare cmdlet creates a Network File System (NFS) file share. To create a share, you must specify a name and a path. If you do not use the optional parameters for this cmdlet, New-NfsShare assigns default values for these share settings.

If you specify a path to a clustered disk for a new NFS share, this cmdlet creates a highly available clustered share. You can use the NetworkName parameter to scope a share to a specified network name. The network name must belong to the same resource group as the clustered disk. If you do not specify the network name, New-NfsShare assigns an arbitrary network name that is available in the same resource group to scope the share.
Specifies the name of the NFS share to create.
Specifies the path of a new NFS share.
Configures the type of global ("All Machines") permissions on the NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Readwrite
- Readonly
- No-access
Specifies the network name of a share.
For a local share, the network name is the host name. For a server cluster, the network name is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

This parameter is not required when you create a local share. In the case of a server cluster, specify the client access point. If you do not specify a network name, New-NfsShare assigns a network name that belongs to the same resource group by default.
Specifies an array of authentication types that an NFS client can use to access NFS shares. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sys (AUTH_SYS authentication) - Krb5 (Kerberos v5 authentication)
- Krb5i (Kerberos v5 authentication with integrity checking)
- Krb5p (Kerberos v5 authentication with privacy)
- All
- Default
If you specify All, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb, Krbi, and Krbp on the share. If you specify Default, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb, and Krbi on the share.
Specifies the user identifier (UID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the group identifier (GID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies language encoding to configure on an NFS share. You can use only one language on the share.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Euc-jp (Japanese)
- Euc-tw (Chinese)
- Euc-kr (Korean)
- Shift-jis (Japanese)
- Big5 (Chinese)
- Ksc5601 (Korean)
- Gb2312-80 (Simplified Chinese)
- Ansi
Configures an NFS share to allow anonymous users to access it.
Configures an NFS share to allow unmapped UNIX users to access a share by using the UID or GID.
Grants the UNIX root user access to a share.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Grants the UNIX root user access to a share.
Specifies the group identifier (GID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the user identifier (UID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).
Specifies an array of authentication types that an NFS client can use to access NFS shares. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sys (AUTH_SYS authentication) - Krb5 (Kerberos v5 authentication)
- Krb5i (Kerberos v5 authentication with integrity checking)
- Krb5p (Kerberos v5 authentication with privacy)
- All
- Default
If you specify All, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb, Krbi, and Krbp on the share. If you specify Default, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb, and Krbi on the share.

For a local share, the network name is the host name. For a server cluster, the network name is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

This parameter is not required when you create a local share. In the case of a server cluster, specify the client access point. If you do not specify a network name, New-NfsShare assigns a network name that belongs to the same resource group by default.
Specifies the path of a new NFS share.
Configures the type of global ("All Machines") permissions on the NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Readwrite
- Readonly
- No-access

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Create an NFS share for a folder ---------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-NfsShare -Name "NFSshare01" -Path "C:\shares\NFSshare01" Name : nfsexport Path : C:\shares\nfsexport NetworkName : GAPRASAD-TST22 Availability : Standard (not clustered) Online : True AnonymousAccess : Disabled AnonymousGID : -2 AnonymousUID : -2 UnmappedUserAccess : Enabled Authentication : {sys, Krb5, Krb5i}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an NFS share named NFSshare01 for sharing the folder C:\shares\NFSshare01.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 2: Create an NFS share that has unmapped access ---

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an NFS share named NFSshare01 for sharing the folder C:\shares\ NFSshare01. This command enables unmapped access on the new share and configures Krb5 and Krb5i authentication on the share.

maml:description.maml:para: Renames a client group on an NFS server.
The Rename-NfsClientGroup cmdlet changes the name of a client group on a Network File System (NFS) server. Renaming a client group does not affect the members of the client.
Specifies the name of the client group to rename.
Specifies a new name for the client group.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

The default is the current session on the local computer.

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 1: Rename a client group by using a name -------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command renames a client group that has the name Contoso-cg1 to Contoso-NewCg.

command:example.maml:title: - Example 2: Rename a client group by using an input pipeline -

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the client group named Contoso-cg1.
The second command then uses the pipeline operator to pass the result to Rename-NfsClientGroup , which renames the client group Contoso-NewCg.

maml:description.maml:para: Resolves the mapping of a Windows user account or group account to a UNIX identifier.
The Resolve-NfsMappedIdentity cmdlet queries a Network File System (NFS) server to resolve the mapping of a Windows user account or group account to a UNIX identifier.

When Resolve-NfsMappedIdentity queries the local NFS server, the local NFS server searches its cache. If the NFS server finds the mapping, the information is returned. If the NFS server mapping does not find the mapping in the server cache, the NFS server queries the configured mapping store. If the NFS server finds the mapping in the mapping store, the mapping is returned, locally cached, and periodically refreshed.

The main purpose of Resolve-NfsMappedIdentity is to perform mapping diagnostics. Administrators can determine whether the NFS server can successfully get the correct mappings for users and groups by using its current configuration.

For more information about NFS, see Network File System Overview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj592688). For more information about NFS account mapping, see NFS Account Mapping Guide (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh509020(v=ws.10)) and [Identity Management for UNIX](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc772571).
Specifies the account name of the user or group to resolve. You can use the AccountType parameter to specify whether the AccountName parameter value represents a user or a group.
Specifies the type of Windows account name or identifier to resolve. Valid values are User and Group.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 1: Resolve a Windows user account to a UNIX UID ---
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Resolve-NfsMappedIdentity -AccountName "PSPinto" -AccountType "User" Windows Account : PSPinto Account Type : User Identifier : 402

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command resolves the Windows user account PSPinto to UNIX user identifier 402. The output reflects the identity mapping that the local NFS server returns.

maml:description.maml:para: Revokes permission to access shares that an NFS server exports.

The Revoke-NfsSharePermission cmdlet revokes permissions previously granted by a Network File System (NFS) server that has an NFS share configured. You can use the Get-NfsSharePermission cmdlet to get a list of the permissions configured on an NFS share.
Specifies the name of an NFS share.
Specifies a client name. The client name can be a host name or IP address, netgroup name, or client group name. To specify the type of client, use the ClientType parameter.
Specifies a client type. Use the builtin client type only when the ClientName parameter value is All Machines. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- host
- clientgroup
- netgroup
- builtin
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.

The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the network name of an NFS share.
For a local share, the network name is the host name. For a cluster, the network name is the network name displayed in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds and removes client computers from a client group.

The Set-NfsClientGroup cmdlet adds and removes client computers from a client group on a Network File System (NFS) server. Use the ClientGroupName parameter to specify a client group to modify. Then, use the AddMember parameter to specify the client computers to add, and use the RemoveMember parameter to specify the client computers to remove.
Specifies the name of a client group.
Specifies an array of host names or IP addresses of client computers to add to the specified client group.
Specifies an array of host names or IP addresses of client computers to remove from the specified client group.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 1: Add a client computer to a client group ------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the client computer that has the IP address 10.121.24.132 to the client group named Contoso-Group2.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 2: Remove a client computer from a client group ---

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the client computer named bill-laptop from the client group named Contoso-Group1.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes configuration settings of an NFS share.

The Set-NfsShare cmdlet changes configuration settings for an existing share that Server for Network File System (NFS) exports. You can use the NetworkName parameter to select a share in a server cluster. NetworkName is not required when you modify configuration settings of non-clustered (standard) shares.
Specifies the name of an NFS share to modify.
Specifies an array of authentication types that an NFS client can use to access NFS shares.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sys (AUTH_SYS authentication) - Krb5 (Kerberos v5 authentication)
- Krb5i (Kerberos v5 authentication with integrity checking)
- Krb5p (Kerberos v5 authentication with privacy)
- All
- Default
If you specify All, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb5, Krb5i, and Krb5p on the share. If you specify Default, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb5, and Krb5i on the share.
Configures the NFS share to allow anonymous users to access it.
Configures the NFS share to allow unmapped UNIX users to access the share by using a UID or GID.
Specifies the group identifier (GID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the user identifier (UID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the language encoding to configure on an NFS share. You can use only one language on the share.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Euc-jp (Japanese)
- Euc-tw (Chinese)
- Euc-kr (Korean)
- Shift-jis (Japanese)
- Big5 (Chinese)
- Ksc5601 (Korean)
- Gb2312-80 (Simplified Chinese)
- Ansi
Grants the UNIX root user access to a share.
Configures the type of global ("All Machines") permissions on the NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Readwrite
- Readonly
- No-access
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the network name of the share. You cannot change the network name of an existing share.
For a local share, the network name is the host name. For a server cluster, the network name is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the path of an NFS share.
Specifies an array of authentication types that an NFS client can use to access NFS shares.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sys (AUTH_SYS authentication) - Krb5 (Kerberos v5 authentication)
- Krb5i (Kerberos v5 authentication with integrity checking)
- Krb5p (Kerberos v5 authentication with privacy)
- All
- Default
If you specify All, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb5, Krb5i, and Krb5p on the share. If you specify Default, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb5, and Krb5i on the share.
Configures the NFS share to allow anonymous users to access it.
Configures the NFS share to allow unmapped UNIX users to access the share by using a UID or GID.
Specifies the group identifier (GID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the user identifier (UID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the language encoding to configure on an NFS share. You can use only one language on the share.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Euc-jp (Japanese)
- Euc-tw (Chinese)
- Euc-kr (Korean)
- Shift-jis (Japanese)
- Big5 (Chinese)
- Ksc5601 (Korean)
- Gb2312-80 (Simplified Chinese)
- Ansi
Grants the UNIX root user access to a share.
Configures the type of global ("All Machines") permissions on the NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Readwrite
- Readonly
- No-access
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Grants the UNIX root user access to a share.
Specifies the group identifier (GID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Specifies the user identifier (UID) that Server for NFS uses for anonymous users who access an NFS share.
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).
Specifies an array of authentication types that an NFS client can use to access NFS shares.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sys (AUTH_SYS authentication) - Krb5 (Kerberos v5 authentication)
- Krb5i (Kerberos v5 authentication with integrity checking)
- Krb5p (Kerberos v5 authentication with privacy)
- All
- Default
If you specify All, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb5, Krb5i, and Krb5p on the share. If you specify Default, Server for NFS configures Sys, Krb5, and Krb5i on the share.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Configures the NFS share to allow anonymous users to access it.
Configures the NFS share to allow unmapped UNIX users to access the share by using a UID or GID.
Specifies the language encoding to configure on an NFS share. You can use only one language on the share.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Euc-jp (Japanese)
- Euc-tw (Chinese)
- Euc-kr (Korean)
- Shift-jis (Japanese)
- Big5 (Chinese)
- Ksc5601 (Korean)
- Gb2312-80 (Simplified Chinese)
- Ansi
Specifies the name of an NFS share to modify.
Specifies the network name of the share. You cannot change the network name of an existing share.
For a local share, the network name is the host name. For a server cluster, the network name is the network name in the resource group to which the share is scoped.
Specifies the path of an NFS share.
Configures the type of global ("All Machines") permissions on the NFS share. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Readwrite
- Readonly
- No-access

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 1: Enable unmapped user access on an NFS share ----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables unmapped users to access the NFS share NFSshare01.

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 2: Set the authentication protocol of an NFS share --

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the authentication protocol as AUTH_SYS and Kerberos v5 on the NFS share NFSshare01. The command also sets the anonymous UID to 100 and the anonymous GID to 200.

maml:description.maml:para: Verifies that an identity mapping store is configured correctly.
The Test-NfsMappingStore cmdlet verifies that you correctly set up and configured an identity mapping store. You can use Get-NfsMappingStore to get the mapping configuration of an NFS server.

For an Active Directory Lightweight Directory Services (AD LDS) store or any other Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) mapping store, the Test-NfsMappingStore cmdlet verifies that a Network File System (NFS) server can reach a configured AD LDS server and that the identity mapping schema is applied.

For an Active Directory mapping store, the Test-NfsMappingStore cmdlet verifies that an NFS server can reach the relevant domain controller, and that the domain functional level is Windows Server 2003 R2 or later
Indicates that this cmdlet runs the command as a background job on a remote computer. Use this parameter to run commands that take an extensive time to finish.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

The default is the current session on the local computer.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

When you use the AsJob parameter, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job finishes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet.

The AsJob parameter resembles using the Invoke-Command cmdlet to run a Start-Job command remotely. However, with AsJob , the job is created on the local computer, even though the job runs on a remote computer, and the results of the remote job are automatically returned to the local computer.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251) and [about_Remote_Jobs](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135184).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Test the configuration of an identity mapping store

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command tests the configuration of an identity mapping store on a local NFS server.
